title: Black-striped wallaby
text:
The black-striped wallaby ("Notamacropus dorsalis"), also known as the scrub wallaby or eastern brush wallaby, is a medium-sized <a href="wallaby">wallaby</a> found in Australia, from <a href="Townsville%2C%20Queensland">Townsville</a> in <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a> to <a href="Narrabri">Narrabri</a> in <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>. In New South Wales, it is only found west of the <a href="Great%20Dividing%20Range">Great Dividing Range</a>. It is decreasing in these areas, but is not classified as threatened as a species yet. The New South Wales population, however, is classified as <a href="endangered">endangered</a>.
The black-striped wallaby resembles the mainland Australian subspecies of the <a href="red-necked%20wallaby">red-necked wallaby</a>, differing in the black line down its back, a white stripe over the hip and more red colouration (extending down the arms and further down the abdomen). It is a shy, <a href="nocturnal">nocturnal</a> grazer and is not well-known, owing to its preference for thick scrub, where it may easily be hidden.
